bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, April 7, 1893

div1.p: Reed writes that he will send money to Blincoe. He asks about her family.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, April 7, 1893

opener.dateline:
Headquarters Department of Dakota,
ATTENDING SURGEON'S OFFICE,
St. Paul, Minn., April 7th, 1893

div1.p:
I believe
that I am your debtor
to the extent of one letter-
I had intended writing,
but have been so busy
with my bacteriological
work -- studying the microbe
of asiatic cholera -- that
I have got much behind
in my correspondence.

I had a long letter from
Pa, a few days ago, and
amongst other things, he re-
ferred to your financial
situation -- and proposed that
Kit and I each contribute
$100 towards helping you along.
I wrote and told him that
I would have to make mine
in two instalments and prom-
ised to send $50 in May and
the other a little later- It
has since occurred to me
that, perhaps, I had better
send the money sooner,
but of this you will be
the best judge. I therefore
write to ask whether you
prefer that I should send
$50 right away, or will it
suit just as well to send
it next month- Consult your
own wishes in this
matter- You know, my darl-
ing sister, how much I regret
that I have been able
to assist you to so slight
an extent, but you understand
why this has been the case.
How do the boys & girls
get along? Is the one, who
went to Washington, still
there? Is Lallie yet in
Mexico? Will she come
home, this Summer? How
is Nita's health? What
a winter we have had
in Minnesota! But we
have all had good health,
which is, after all, the great-
-est blessing one can have.
Now, please, write very promptly
and let me know whether
your health is good and
your spirits cheerful-
Best love from us
all to you and yours.
address your letter accord-
ing to heading of this letter.
